Not quite as authoritative as PBS, but the Doonesbury comic strip touched on "the dancing boys of Afghanistan" several years back. In the strip, local leaders tell villagers not to present that part of the evening's "entertainment" to the Americans present at an event. This tells me that, rather than "the press" keeping this hidden until now, it was pretty widely seen as a problem in some parts of the U.S. public back then.

Also, I'm sure the Afghan women and children subjected to these horrific crimes are not eager to "protect" these supposed "cultural norms".

PBS Frontline did a whole documentary in 2010 on this abominable sexual exploitation of boys in Afghanistan, called "The Dancing Boys of Afghanistan." You can watch it here: http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/dancingboys/

Wonderful recipe.  For the "green" factor I threw in some good frozen spinach into the caramelized onions before returning the sausage.  It did not add unnecessary moisture, and made a more complete one-pot meal.

This is a strange comment. Does this man know that the British raped the whole of india, plundered it, dertroyed its industries, murdered entire groups of people. It committed much greater atrocities than the ones he has stated,which were likely rather uncommon.

Abolishing this practice would be great, but at what cost? More of America's sons and daughters, and while further destabilizing the region through continuous warfare? British occupation of India created far more problems than it solved, and it culminated with the deaths of 15 million Bengalese farmers who Churchill intentionally starved. Thuggee and Suttee were isolated practices anyway. The lesson from history is that the sooner we stop invoking the rite of enlightened despotism, the better off the world will be.

Purely in the interest of facts, and not to defend anybody, "Suttee" (aka Sati) and "Thuggee" were very local events to the province of Bengal. While they are clearly horrific practices, they were not common or widespread.

Sati (Suttee) was a sort of "death before dishonor" notion, where a widow would leap into the funeral pyre of her husband so she would join him in Heaven. It was practiced in some royal clans when the king or prince was killed in battle and his wife/wives fearing violation by the invading forces would take their lives in massive funeral pyres. Again, this was a very local phenomenon and not something 90% of the population did.

Thuggees were nothing to do with "ritual murder" (what does that even mean?) They were bandits who tricked travelers, killed them and stole their property. Ancient India was like the "Wild West", a land being settled by different outside invaders (some people contest the Aryan invasion, but the NW Frontier seems to have been invaded by Central Asians for ages...) There used to be extensive trade between provinces, and often gold and silver were part of the transaction. Just like holding up a train and robbing it was lucrative, stealing from traveling businessmen (returning with gold and silver after selling their wares) was lucrative, and the Thuggees were a secretive band of thieves who operated like a mafia or cult (Omerta, etc)

The Pentagon should not have condoned "Bacha Bazi" on our watch. We failed our own moral code.

During their colonial occupation of India, the British attempted to abolish some of the most objectionable indigenous practices, such as Thuggee (ritual murder) and Suttee (widow burning). Many Indians today agree that this was one of the positive legacies of colonial rule. Wouldn't it be great if before getting out of Afghanistan (which I hope is very very soon), we could take credit for abolishing "boy play."

So in other words just run away and ignore millions of victims? Unfortunately it was the spineless people that told obama they wouldn't give him any more campaign money unless we pulled out of Iraq and NOW even Europe is suffering the consequences of his stupidity and greed.
Too much is bring asked of our troops. It is time to bring them home. I know more than I ever want to about Afghanistan. They do too.

Very good. The whiskey adds a sharpness that perfectly offsets the chocolate, without adding enough alcohol to put off kids. We loved it and would make again.

Yes, I have made that mistake, but fortunately realized who the person was before embarrassing myself. This has happened more than once, by the way, and, I must admit, more often with persons of color.

This sort of thing happens between people from different families, also. Many times when my children were growing up, others confused two of my daughters for twins, saying that they looked so much alike. They really didn't look that much alike to me or to others within the family.

I think you completely misunderstood the purpose of the exercise. Your fourth point was the whole point of the puzzle! Yes, if you guessed 0 it means you think almost everyone who answered the puzzle has the mathematical skills to find one of the Nash equilibria. But it also means you think that everyone else thinks that as well.

It's an exercise in human behavior disguised as a math puzzle, not a math puzzle.

The concept of a "free-market" is a just a rhetorical device used by the advertisers in pay of the business class. The business class understands that state power is a tremendous prize, and that, in a more-or-less democratic system such as ours, the state is up for grabs and will be taken by those who can craft the most effective slogans in support of themselves and their agents. Free-market rhetoric appeals to the middle-level people who believe that in a free-er market they'd stand a better chance of moving up in the world. It appeals to their values of hard work, thrift, and a level playing field without any government crowding-out. Ironically, they go and vote for the peddlers of this rhetoric who have zero intention whatsoever of handing the reins over the middle level people now that the state is in their hands. Instead, the lucrative state contracts will be going to them and their buddies and the positions of the two classes will barely change (if at all). Trump isn't just an astute businessman, he is very smart. He knows how this game works.

But it's not three people, it's 60,000 people (at the moment). If 60,000 people guess 1 then the most correct answer is 1. So which will it converge to? Well, imagine playing the game a thousand times. The first few times I suspect the average guess will get lower and lower but remain higher than 1, so each of those times 1 and not 0 will be the more correct answer (if we play again and you had to choose either 0 or 1, surely you would guess that 1 would be closer?). So it will at least appear to converge to 1. Now think -- at what point do you think that the tens of thousands of readers correctly guessing 1 are going to suddenly jump from 1 to 0?

I think the mathematical answer, as others have said, is that there are two Nash equilibria, 1 and 0, but I think human nature more suggests a convergence towards 1 and not zero.

Is this also the reasoning behind people seeming to look less and less unique the more they age? In researching ancestry and viewing photos of people in their younger days versus their current appearance, one can't help but notice that even strikingly attractive people seem to lose what, for lack of a better phrase, I would call individual facial distinctiveness.

No, it doesn't, because a mistake due to something innate that is not the fault of the viewer is not racism. That said, the suggestion that exposure at an early age to a diverse group of persons might correct this innate tendency is definitely worth exploring, because, obviously, the correction of any behavior that, to its objects, has the same destructive effect as racism is desirable.

It's a hard call. But I'm glad that parents have the option to find extra help in this loaded college admissions process, at least if they can afford it. As far as the engineering path, our son went for a 3/2 program, where he spent 3 years at a small liberal arts college and then shifted into a larger university for chemical engineering. It will cost a lot more (a surprise to us), but we did like that he had the opportunity to take a wide swath of courses, including art, philosophy and other humanities, before hitting the intense engineering curriculum.

For scrappy students and parents looking for great and free resources, check out my www.essayhell blog that offers an unimaginable amount of FREE tips, advice and instruction on how to nail the dreaded college application essay (and the reality is most private college admissions counselors are not writers and have limited expertise on this all-important piece of the application process.)

For what it's worth, my husband and I didn't hire a professional counselor to guide our two children and they both landed in excellent colleges. If you have the time and energy to do your own research (and that is a big if), it's not rocket science and your student will land where they are meant to go---whether you dish out the $3K+ or not. It's all about the fit and the path. Trust it!

One can tell an immediate difference in the value of the college choice by when one must declare a major.

At the better colleges, one does not have to declare a major until late into the second year of undergraduate work. A student just out of high school has no clue as to what the world is like and until one has exposure to a wide range of fields, it is rather futile to obligate oneself to committing to a major.

I guess the easy thing is to blame "Easy E" for the fumbles and the loss.  However, the sacks (and fumbles) came because the line had become completely porous.  As soon as Flowers, our rookie LT, went down, the line fell apart. When John Jerry is your first O-line sub, you have a very large problem.  If Flowers can't play Thursday, we may face another loss, this time to the most confused franchise in the NFL.
